questions.question: Who were the first people to live in Britain?
questions.explanation: The earliest people in Britain were hunter-gatherers who lived during the Stone Age.

questions.question: How was Britain connected to Europe during the Stone Age?
questions.explanation: A land bridge once connected Britain to mainland Europe during the Stone Age.

questions.question: When did Britain become separated from the continent by the Channel?
questions.explanation: Rising sea levels created the Channel and separated Britain around 10,000 years ago.

questions.question: Where did the first farmers in Britain probably come from?
questions.explanation: The first farmers likely came from south-east Europe about 6,000 years ago.

questions.question: What is Stonehenge believed to have been used for?
questions.explanation: Stonehenge was probably a special site for seasonal ceremonies.

questions.question: What is Skara Brae known for?
choices: Being the best-preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe
Being the largest Iron Age hill fort
questions.explanation: Skara Brae on Orkney is the best-preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe.

questions.question: What material gave the Bronze Age its name?
questions.explanation: The Bronze Age is named for the discovery of how to make bronze tools and objects.

questions.question: What language family did Iron Age people in Britain speak?
questions.explanation: Iron Age Britons spoke Celtic languages, still related to those in parts of Wales, Scotland, and Ireland.

questions.question: Which British queen led a revolt against the Romans?
questions.explanation: Boudicca, queen of the Iceni tribe, led a famous revolt against the Romans.
